recommendations: CT Chest Angiography (CTA) for Pulmonary Embolism should be considered to evaluate for acute pulmonary embolism given the patient's symptoms of right-sided chest pain and presentation as an emergency.

Given the patient's elevated creatinine (1.7 mg/dL) and moderate CKD (eGFR 59 mL/min/1.73m²), administer IV fluids pre- and post-contrast according to ACR guidelines to mitigate contrast-induced nephropathy risk.
Monitor renal function post-imaging due to the potential risk of contrast-induced nephropathy.
rationale: Patient presents with right-sided chest pain, a common symptom of pulmonary embolism.
eGFR of 59 mL/min/1.73m² indicates Stage 3a CKD, increasing risk of contrast-induced nephropathy.
Hypotension (MAP 59 mmHg) further increases risk of contrast-induced nephropathy.
CT Chest Angiography is the standard imaging modality for diagnosing pulmonary embolism.
Hydration protocols are recommended by ACR for patients with renal insufficiency undergoing contrast-enhanced CT.

protocol_selection.name: CT Pulmonary Angiography (Chest CTA for PE)
protocol_selection.description: CT angiography timed for pulmonary arterial phase (6–13 sec post-contrast) to evaluate pulmonary arteries for embolism.
protocol_selection.contrast_dose: Weight-based; ~100–150 mL iodinated contrast (300 mg I/mL); follow ACR Manual.
protocol_selection.renal_safety_notes: Ensure contrast-to-eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min); if eGFR <30, consider non-contrast alternatives or weigh risks carefully.
